application.name: jigsaw
application.brief: Improves camera pointing and a whole lot more!

description.p: The jigsaw application performs a bundle adjustment on a group of overlapping Isis 3, level 1, cubes from framing and/or line-scan cameras. The adjustment simultaneously defines the selected image geometry information (camera pointing, spacecraft position) and control point coordinates (x,y,z or lat,lon,radius) to reduce boundary mismatches in mosaics of the images.

This functionality is demonstrated below in a zoomed-in area of a mosaic of a pair of overlapping Messenger images. In the before jigsaw mosaic on the left (uncontrolled), the features on the edges of the images do not match. In the after jigsaw mosaic on the right (controlled), the crater edges meet correctly and the seam between the two images is no longer visible.

The jigsaw application assumes spiceinit has been run on the input cubes so that SPICE is included in the Isis 3 cube labels in the Kernels group. In order to run the program, the user must provide a list of input cubes, an input control net, the name of an output control net, and the adjustment parameters. jigsaw outputs a new control net that includes the initial state of the points in the network and their final state after the adjustment. The initial states of the points are tagged as a priori in the control net, and their final states are tagged as adjusted. The measured sample/line positions associated with the control points in the net are not changed. SPICE in the cube labels is updated at the end of the adjustment only if the bundle converges and the UPDATE parameter is selected.

Optional output files can be selected to provide more information for analyzing the results. BUNDLEOUT_TXT provides an overall summary of the bundle adjustment. It lists the user input parameters selected and tables of statistics for both the images and the points. The image statistics can also be written to a separate CSV file and likewise for the point statistics with the OUTPUT_CSV option selected. RESIDUALS_CSV provides a table of the measured image coordinates and the final sample, line, and overall residuals in both millimeters and pixels.

The functional model for the bundle adjustment is the collinearity condition. It stipulates that the camera perspective center, a ground point, and its associated image point measurement be collinear. The diagram below demonstrates the collinear condition in a bundle adjustment. The vectors formed by connecting each object space point (target surface x,y,z) and its corresponding image space points (sample,line) form a bundle of light rays.
Kraus, Karl., 1993. Photogrammetry Vol. I., Fundamentals and Standard Processes, Der. DÃ¼mmler Verlag, Bonn, Germany, ISBN 3-427-78684-6, 397 pages.

blockquote.b: Running jigsaw with a control net containing JigsawRejected flags may result in bundle failure
blockquote.p:
When running jigsaw with Outlier Rejection turned on, control points and/or control measures may be flagged as JigsawRejected in the output control net file. If this output net file is then used in a subsequent jigsaw run, these points and measures will be erroneously ignored, potentially causing the bundle adjustment to fail.
--Workarounds
Run jigsaw with Outlier Rejection off.
Do not use the output control net file in subsequent jigsaw runs.
Convert the output control net file from binary to PVL and back using cnetbin2pvl and cnetpvl2bin. This will clear the JigsawRejected flags.

history.change: Original version
Changed category to Control Networks and corrected XML bugs
Revised iteration report to list the errors and sigmas from the same iteration. Previous version reported errors from previous iteration and sigmas from current iteration.
Cleaned the Bundle Adjust memory leak and fixed the app tests.
Added date to the Jigged comment in the spice tables.
If updating pointing, delete the CameraStatistics table from labels.
Modified program to write history to input cubes.
Commented out Heldlist until mechanism in place to enter individual image parameter constraints.
Merged Ken Edmundson version with system and binary control net.
Modified code to prevent updates to cube files in held list.

Removed SC_SIGMAS from user parameter list because it is not fully implemented; changed method name SPARSE to OLDSPARSE and CHOLMOD to SPARSE; and improved the documentation for the Isis3.3.0 release.

history.change: Added images showing before and after to demonstrate the program. Added Krause's collinearity diagram and a brief explanation on the output options. Also added a lien for example(s) to be added later.
Corrected previous history entry and added references to glossary. Also changed application names to bold type.

change.name: Debbie A. Cook and Ken Edmundson

history.change: Removed glossary references from briefs. Also changed the definition of angles to state right ascension and declination to be consistent with the output.
Added internal default and minimum inclusive tags to global apriori uncertainties.
Added Known Issues section and JigsawRejected flag issue.
Added minimums to parameters, corrected SOLVEDEGREE description, and added to the camsolve option descriptions in response to Mantis issue #514.
Added REJECTION_MULTIPLIER to interface, part of Mantis issue #637.
Added SPKDEGREE and SPKSOLVEDEGREE; changed name of SOLVEDEGREE to CKSOLVEDEGREE.
Added separate group for Error Propagation with option to write inverse matrix to binary file. For extremely large networks where memory/time for error propagation is limited.
Added USEPVL and SC_PARAMETERS parameters.

Modified appTests to use SPARSE method only. Commented out bundleout_images.csv references. Created observationSolveSettings() method to create an observation settings object from the user entered values.
Added preliminary target body functionality. Added SOLVETARGETBODY and TB_PARAMETERS.
Added a connection to allow jigsaw to surface exceptions from BundleAdjust. Fixes #2302

Removed the user parameter called METHOD (i.e. the method used for solving the bundle matrix). This solve method is no longer user-selected. The program will now use what was called the SPARSE option for the METHOD parameter (i.e. solve with CholMod sparse decomposition). This method should give the same results as the other options and should run faster. So the other options were no longer needed. References #4162.
Reviewed documentation and updated small spelling and grammar errors. References #4226.
Updated how jigsaw handles its prefix parameter along with a small documentation change. Fixes #4309.
Updated how input parameters are output when using multiple sensor solve settings. Fixes #4316.
Output from jigsaw will again provide "Validating network" and "Validation complete" messages to inform user that their control network has been validated. Fixes #4313.
When running jigsaw with error propagation turned on, the correlation matrix file, inverseMatrix.dat, is no longer generated. Fixes #4315.
Added the IMAGES_CSV parameter to the "Output Options" group so that the user can now request the bundleout_images.csv file in addition to the other output files such as bundleout.txt. Fixes #4314.

Implemented HELDLIST functionality for non-overlapping held images. Any control points that intersect the held images are fixed, and a priori surface points for these control points are set to the held images' measures' surface points. Disabled USEPVL/SC_PARAMETERS. Fixes #4293.
Added the "Generating report files" and Rejected_Measures keyword back to jigsaw's standard output. Fixes #4461. Fixed spacing in standard output. Fixes #4462, #4463."

The bundleout.txt output file will record default values for unsolved parameters. The default position will be the instrument position's center coordinate, and the default pointing will be the pointing's (rotation's) center angles. The bundleout_images.csv file will also have these defaults provided. Fixes #4464.
Removed the underscores from the new parameters IMAGESCSV and TBPARAMETERS.
Exceptions that occur during the solving of the bundle adjustment will now pop up as message boxes when running jigsaw in GUI mode. Fixes #4483.
Output control net will be now be written regardless of whether bundle converges. Fixes #4533.
Updated description and brief for SOLVETARGETBODY and TBPARAMETERS.
Fixed bug where an invalid control net was not throwing exception. Fixes #5068.
Modifed call to bundleAdjustment->solveCholeskyBR() to return a raw pointer to a BundleSolutionInfo object. Am also deleting this pointer because jigsaw.cpp takes ownership from BundleAdjust.

parameter.name: FROMLIST
parameter.brief: List of cubes in the input control network
parameter.description: This file contains a list of all cubes in the control network

parameter.name: HELDLIST
parameter.brief: List of (non-overlapping) cubes to hold in the adjustment
parameter.description: This file contains a list of all cubes whose orientation and position will be held in the adjustment. These images will still be included in the solution, but their camera orientation and spacecraft position will be constrained to keep the values from changing. This is an optional parameter and the default is to not hold any of the images. Note that held images must not overlap each other to work properly.

parameter.name: CNET
parameter.brief: Input control network
parameter.description: This file is a control network generated from programs such as autoseed or qnet. It contains the control points and associated measures.

parameter.name: ONET
parameter.brief: Output control network
parameter.description: This output file contains the updated control network with the final coordinates of the control points and residuals for each measurement.

parameter.name: OBSERVATIONS
parameter.brief: Keep instances of the same observation in different cube files the same
parameter.description: This option will solve for SPICE on all cubes with a matching observation number as though they were a single observation. For most missions, the default observation number is equivalent to the serial number of the cube, and a single cube is an observation. However, for the Lunar Orbiter mission, an image has a defined observation number that is a substring of its serial number. This feature allows the three subframes of a Lunar Orbiter High Resolution frame to be treated as a single observation when this option is used; otherwise, each subframe is adjusted independently.

parameter.name: RADIUS
parameter.brief: Solve for local radii of points
parameter.description: Select this option to solve for the local radius of each control point. If this button is not turned on, the radii of the points will not change from the cube's shape model.

parameter.name: UPDATE
parameter.brief: Update cube label
parameter.description: When this option is selected, the application will update the labels of the individual cubes in the FROMLIST with the final values from the solution if the adjustment converges. The results are written to the SPICE blobs attached to the cube, overwriting the previous values. If this option is not selected, the cube files are not changed. All other output files are still created.

parameter.name: OUTLIER_REJECTION
parameter.brief: Auto-rejection of outliers
parameter.description: Select this option to perform automatic outlier detection and rejection.

parameter.name: REJECTION_MULTIPLIER
parameter.brief: Rejection multiplier
parameter.description: Rejection multiplier

parameter.name: ERRORPROPAGATION
parameter.brief: Compute variance-covariance matrix
parameter.description: Select this option to compute the variance-covariance matrix of the parameters. The parameter uncertainties can be computed from this matrix.

parameter.name: MODEL1
parameter.brief: A maximum likelihood estimation model selection
parameter.description: A maximum likelihood estimation model selection.

option.brief: None: no tier one maximum likelihood estimation
option.description: None: no tier one maximum likelihood estimation

option.brief: Huber: approximates the L2 norm near 0, and the L1 norm thereafter. Has one continuous derivative.
option.description: A highly recommended model that works well in many situations.

option.brief: Huber Modified: approximates the L2 norm near 0 and the L1 norm thereafter. Has two continuous derivatives.
option.description: An adaptation of the highly recommended Huber model that has two continuous derivatives.

parameter.name: MAX_MODEL1_C_QUANTILE
parameter.brief: Quantile of the |residual| distribution used to set the tweaking constant of the maximum likelihood estimation model
parameter.description: The tweaking constant has different meanings depending on the model being used: Huber models: The point at which the transformation motion from L2 to L1 norms takes place. Recommended quantile: 0.5 Welsch model: Residuals whose absolute value is twice the tweaking constant are approaching negligible significance. Recommended quantile: 0.7 Chen model: Residuals whose absolute value is greater than the tweaking constant are totally ignored. Recommended quantile: > 0.9

parameter.name: MODEL2
parameter.brief: A maximum likelihood estimation model selection
parameter.description: A maximum likelihood estimation model selection.

option.brief: None: no tier two maximum likelihood estimation
option.description: None: no tier two maximum likelihood estimation

option.brief: Huber: approximates the L2 norm near 0, and the L1 norm thereafter. Has one continuous derivative.
option.description: A highly recommended model that works well in many situations.

option.brief: Huber Modified: approximates the L2 norm near 0 and the L1 norm thereafter. Has two continuous derivatives.
option.description: An adaptation of the highly recommended Huber model that has two continuous derivatives.

option.brief: Welsch: approximates the L2 norm near 0, but then decays exponentially to zero.
option.description: This model reduces the significance of large residuals more aggressively than Huber. Large residuals will have less influence than small residuals, and they approach negligibility as they approach infinity. Measures can be effectively 'removed' by this method, which may cause singularities and/or islands.

option.brief: Chen: a highly aggressive method that intentionally removes the largest few percent of residuals.
option.description: This method dramatically increases the influence of smaller residuals (beyond the L2 norm) while simultaneously totally ignoring the largest few percent of the residuals.

parameter.name: SIGMA0
parameter.brief: Standard deviation of unit weight
parameter.description: Converges on stabilization of Sigma0. Convergence occurs when the change in sigma0 between iterations is less than or equal to Sigma0.

parameter.name: MAXITS
parameter.brief: Maximum number of iterations
parameter.description: Maximum number of times to iterate. The application stops iterating at MAXIT, or when convergence is reached.

parameter.name: CKDEGREE
parameter.brief: Degree of polynomial fit to original camera angles
parameter.description: The degree of the polynomial fit to the original camera angles and used to generate a priori camera angles for the first iteration.

parameter.name: CKSOLVEDEGREE
parameter.brief: The degree of the polynomial being fit to in the bundle adjustment
parameter.description: The degree of the polynomial being fit to in the bundle adjust solution. This polynomial can be different from the one used to generate the a priori camera angles used in the first iteration. In the case of an instrument with a jitter problem, a higher degree polynomial fit to each of the camera angles might provide a better solution (smaller errors). For framing cameras, the application automatically sets degree to 0.

parameter.name: CAMSOLVE
parameter.brief: Camera pointing parameters to include in the bundle adjustment
parameter.description: This parameter is used to specify which, if any, camera pointing parameters to include in the adjustment.

option.brief: Don't solve for any camera pointing factors
option.description: If this option is selected, no camera pointing parameters will be adjusted.

option.brief: Solve for camera angles: right ascension, declination and optionally twist
option.description: Camera angles in each cube will be adjusted in the solution, but not angular velocities or accelerations. Solving for the first two camera angles translates images in sample and line. Adding the third angle to the solution (TWIST option) allows for rotation corrections. Adjustments are not applied unless the solution converges and UPDATE is selected. Solving for angles only is equivalent to using CKSOLVEDEGREE=0.

option.brief: Solve for camera angles AND their angular velocities
option.description: Camera angles and their angular velocities will be adjusted in the solution. Solving for angles and velocities is equivalent to using CKSOLVEDEGREE=1.

option.brief: Solve for camera angles, their angular velocities and accelerations
option.description: Camera angles, their angular velocities, and accelerations will be adjusted in the solution. Solving for angles, angular velocities, and accelerations is equivalent to using CKSOLVEDEGREE=2.

option.brief: Solve for all coefficients in the polynomials fit to the camera angles.
option.description: If this option is selected, all coefficients of the solve equation will be adjusted in the solution (CKSOLVEDEGREE+1 coefficients)

parameter.name: TWIST
parameter.brief: Solve for twist
parameter.description: If this option is selected, the twist angle will be adjusted in the bundle adjustment solution.

parameter.name: OVEREXISTING
parameter.brief: Fit polynomial over the existing pointing
parameter.description:
This option will fit a polynomial over the existing pointing data. This data is held constant in the adjustment, and the initial value for the each of the coefficients in the polynomials is 0.
When this option is used, the current pointing is used as a priori in the adjustment.

parameter.name: SPKDEGREE
parameter.brief: Degree of polynomial fit to original camera position
parameter.description: The degree of the polynomial fit to the original camera position and used to generate a priori camera positions for the first iteration.

parameter.name: SPKSOLVEDEGREE
parameter.brief: The degree of the camera position polynomial being fit to in the bundle adjustment.
parameter.description: The degree of the polynomial being fit to in the bundle adjust solution. This polynomial can be different from the one used to generate the a priori camera positions used in the first iteration. In the case of an instrument with a jitter problem, a higher degree polynomial fit for the camera position might provide a better solution (smaller errors). For framing cameras, the application automatically sets degree to 0.

parameter.name: SPSOLVE
parameter.brief: Spacecraft position parameters to include in the adjustment
parameter.description: This parameter is used to specify which, if any, spacecraft position parameters to include in the adjustment.

option.brief: Don't solve for any spacecraft position parameters
option.description: No spacecraft position parameters will be adjusted.

option.brief: Solve for the spacecraft positions
option.description: Spacecraft positions will be adjusted in the solution, but not the velocity or the acceleration.

option.brief: Solve for the spacecraft positions and velocities
option.description: Spacecraft positions will be adjusted in the solution, as well as the velocities of the spacecraft at each instance.

option.brief: Solve for the spacecraft positions, velocities, and accelerations
option.description: Spacecraft positions will be adjusted in the solution, as well as the velocities and accelerations of the spacecraft at each instance.

option.brief: Solve for all coefficients in the polynomials fit to the camera position.
option.description: If this option is selected, all coefficients of the solve equation will be adjusted in the solution (SPKSOLVEDEGREE+1 coefficients)

parameter.name: OVERHERMITE
parameter.brief: Fit polynomial over the existing Hermite spline
parameter.description:
This option will fit a polynomial over the existing Hermite cubic spline used to interpolate the coordinates of the spacecraft position. The spline is held constant in the adjustment, and the initial value for the each of the coefficients in the polynomials is 0.
When this option is used, the current positions are used as a priori in the adjustment.

parameter.name: SOLVETARGETBODY
parameter.brief: Solve for target body parameters. The parameters, their a priori values, and uncertainties are input using a PVL file specified by TBPARAMETERS below.
parameter.description: Solve for target body parameters. The parameters, their a priori values, and uncertainties are input using a PVL file specified by TBPARAMETERS below. An example template PVL file is located at $base/templates/jigsaw/TargetBodyParameters.pvl.

parameter.name: TBPARAMETERS
parameter.brief: File containing target body parameters to solve for, their a priori values and uncertainties.
parameter.description: This file contains target body parameters to solve for in the bundle adjustment, their a priori values, and uncertainties. The file must be in PVL format. An example template PVL file is located at $base/templates/jigsaw/TargetBodyParameters.pvl. Instructions for the PVL structure are given in the template.

parameter.name: POINT_LATITUDE_SIGMA
parameter.brief: Global latitude uncertainty for all points (meters)
parameter.description: This optional value will be used as the global latitude uncertainty for all points. Units are meters.

parameter.name: POINT_LONGITUDE_SIGMA
parameter.brief: Global longitude uncertainty for all points (meters)
parameter.description: This optional value will be used as the global longitude uncertainty for all points. Units are meters.

parameter.name: POINT_RADIUS_SIGMA
parameter.brief: Global radius uncertainty for all points (meters)
parameter.description: This value will be used as the global radius uncertainty for all points. Units are meters.

parameter.name: SPACECRAFT_POSITION_SIGMA
parameter.brief: Global uncertainty for spacecraft coordinates (meters)
parameter.description: This value will be used as the global uncertainty for spacecraft coordinates. Units are meters.

parameter.name: SPACECRAFT_VELOCITY_SIGMA
parameter.brief: Global uncertainty for spacecraft velocity (meters/second)
parameter.description: This value will be used as the global uncertainty for spacecraft velocity. Units are meters/second.

parameter.name: SPACECRAFT_ACCELERATION_SIGMA
parameter.brief: Global uncertainty for spacecraft acceleration (meters/second/second)
parameter.description: This value will be used as the global uncertainty for spacecraft acceleration. Units are meters/second/second.

parameter.name: CAMERA_ANGLES_SIGMA
parameter.brief: global uncertainty for camera angles (decimal degrees)
parameter.description: This value will be used as the global uncertainty for camera angles. Units are decimal degrees.

parameter.name: CAMERA_ANGULAR_VELOCITY_SIGMA
parameter.brief: Global uncertainty for camera angular velocity (decimal degrees/second)
parameter.description: This value will be used as the global uncertainty for camera angular velocity. Units are decimal degrees/second.

parameter.name: CAMERA_ANGULAR_ACCELERATION_SIGMA
parameter.brief: Global uncertainty for camera angular acceleration (decimal degrees/second/second)
parameter.description: This value will be used as the global uncertainty for camera angular acceleration. Units are decimal degrees/second/second.

parameter.name: FILE_PREFIX
parameter.brief: Output file prefix
parameter.description: File prefix to prepend for the generated output files. Any prefix that is not a file path will have an underscore placed between the prefix and file name.

parameter.name: BUNDLEOUT_TXT
parameter.brief: Standard bundle output file - bundleout.txt
parameter.description: Selection of this parameter flags generation of the standard bundle output file

parameter.name: IMAGESCSV
parameter.brief: Outputs image data (body-fixed) to csv file - bundleout_images.csv
parameter.description: Selection of this parameter flags output of image data (in body-fixed coordinates) to a csv file.

parameter.name: OUTPUT_CSV
parameter.brief: Outputs point and image data (body-fixed) to csv file - bundleout_points.csv
parameter.description: Selection of this parameter flags output of point and image data (in body-fixed coordinates) to csv file.

parameter.name: RESIDUALS_CSV
parameter.brief: Outputs image coordinate residuals to csv file - residuals.csv
parameter.description: Selection of this parameter flags output of image coordinate residuals to a csv file
